TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, frigid Vitrandic Dystrochrepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Buttecreek gravelly loam, forested, on a 74 percent slope at 3,800 feet elevation.  Aspect is west.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise indicated)
Oe--2 to 0 inches; slightly decomposed needles, twigs, leaves and moss
A--0 to 2 inches; brown (7.5YR 4/3) gravelly loam, dark brown (7.5YR 3/3) moist; weak fine and medium granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; many very fine roots throughout; many very fine irregular pores; 5 percent fine mica flakes; 15 percent subangular gravel; moderately acid (pH 6.0); abrupt wavy boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
Bw1--2 to 9 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) gravelly loam, dark brown (7.5YR 3/4) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and common fine and medium roots throughout; many fine irregular and few fine tubular pores; 5 percent fine mica flakes; 15 percent subangular gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.2); clear wavy boundary.
Bw2--9 to 14 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) gravelly sandy loam, dark brown (7.5YR 3/4) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; few fine and common medium and coarse roots throughout; 5 percent fine mica flakes; 20 percent subangular gravel; moderately acid (pH 6.0); abrupt wavy boundary.  (Combined thickness of Bw horizons is 11 to 18 inches thick)
2Bw3--14 to 31 inches; pink (7.5YR 7/3) very gravelly sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots between peds; common fine irregular and tubular pores; 10 percent fine mica flakes; 40 percent subangular gravel and 2 percent subangular cobbles; strongly acid (pH 5.4); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 17 inches thick)
2BC--31 to 45 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) very gravelly sandy loam, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots between peds; common fine irregular and tubular pores; 15 percent fine mica flakes; 55 percent subangular gravel; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 14 inches thick)
2C--45 to 60 inches; pink (7.5YR 7/4) extremely gravelly sandy loam, reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) moist; weak fine and very fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few medium roots throughout; few fine and medium irregular and tubular pores; 35 percent fine mica flakes; 80 percent subangular gravel; very strongly acid (pH 4.6).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Clearwater County, Idaho; about 11 miles north and 3 miles east of Headquarters, Idaho, about 1,500 feet north and 950 feet east of the SW corner of Sec. 29, T.40N, R.6E.  Latitude - 46 degrees, 46 minutes and 45 seconds North, Longitude - 115 degrees, 44 minutes and 21 seconds West.  USGS Thompson Point Quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Soil moisture control section - not dry for 45 consecutive days between June and October
Average annual soil temperature - 41 to 46 degrees F.
Thickness of Vitrandic feature - 14 to 18 inches
Base saturation - 35 to 60 percent throughout
A horizon
Hue - 10YR or 7.5YR
Chroma - 2 or 3 moist
Volcanic glass content in the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction - 5 to 25 percent Acid-oxalate extractable Al+1/2Fe - 0.40 to 0.70 percent
Phosphate retention - 30 to 45 percent 15-bar water retention in air-dried samples - 8 to 12 percent
Bulk density - 0.95 to 1.10 g/cc
Textures - L or GR-L
Clay content - 10 to 14 percent
Rock fragments - 0 to 15 percent gravel
Reaction - moderately acid to neutral
Bw horizons
Hue - 10YR or 7.5YR
Value - 4 to 6 dry, 4 to 6 moist
Chroma - 3 to 6 dry
Volcanic glass content - 5 to 25 percent
Acid-oxalate extractable Al+1/2Fe - 0.40 to 0.70 percent
Phosphate retention - 30 to 45 percent 15-bar water retention on air-dried samples - 8 to 12 percent
Bulk density - 1.04 to 1.30 g/cc
Textures - L, GR-L, GR-SL
Clay content - 8 to 16 percent
Rock fragments - 0 to 20 percent gravel
Reaction - moderately acid to neutral
2Bw horizon
Hue - 7.5YR or 10YR
Value - 5 to 7 dry, 3 to 6 moist
Chroma - 3 or 4 dry, 4 to 6 moist
Clay content - 12 to 18 percent
Rock fragments - 35 to 55 percent gravel and 0 to 2 percent cobbles; total rock fragment content is 35 to 55 percent
Reaction - strongly acid to slightly acid
2BC horizon
Value - 5 to 7 dry, 4 to 6 moist
Chroma - 3 or 4 dry, 3 to 6 moist
Clay content - 12 to 14 percent
Rock fragments - 35 to 55 percent gravel and 0 to 5 percent cobbles; total rock fragment content is 35 to 55 percent
Reaction - strongly acid to slightly acid
2C horizons
Hue - 7.5YR to 2.5Y
Value - 5 to 7 dry, 4 to 6 moist
Chroma - 3 or 4 dry, 3 to 6 moist
Textures - GRX-SL, GRV-LS, CBV-LS
Clay content - 6 to 12 percent
Rock fragments - 35 to 80 percent gravel, 0 to 30 percent cobbles and 0 to 10 percent stones; total rock fragment content is 40 to 80 percent Reaction - very strongly acid to moderately acid

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no other series in this family.  The Marblecreek series is in a closely related family.  Marblecreek soils have andric soil properties 7 to 14 inches thick.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Buttecreek soils are on mountain slopes and canyons at elevations of 2,000 to 4,800 feet.  Slopes are 35 to 95 percent.  These soils formed in material weathered from gneiss and schist with v+Rolcanic ash influences in the upper part.  The average annual temperature ranges from 40 to 45 degrees F.  The average annual precipitation ranges from 35 to 45 inches.  The frost free period is 70 to 90 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Aldermand, Rettig(T), and Grandad(T) series.  Aldermand soils have less than 35 percent rock fragments in the particle-size control section and are found on canyon and mountain slopes.  Rettig(T) soils have less the 35 percent rock fragments and 25 to 80 percent mica in the particle-size control section and are found on mountain slopes and ridges.  Grandad(T) soils have less than 35 percent rock fragments in the particle-size control section and an argillic horizon and are found on mountain slopes and ridgetops.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; rapid to very rapid runoff; moderate permeability in the upper part and moderately rapid to rapid permeability in the lower part

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used primarily for timber production, wildlife habitat and watershed.  The vegetation is mainly western redcedar, Douglas fir, grand fir and western larch with an understory of queencup beadlily, goldthread, common prince's pine, darkwoods violet, longtube twinflower and rustyleaf menziesia.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  North-central Idaho.  These soils are not extensive

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Clearwater County, Idaho, 1995. The name is from a local stream.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and other features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - the zone from the surface to 2 inches (A horizon)
Cambic horizon - the zone from 2 to 31 inches (Bw1, Bw2, 2Bw3 horizons)
Vitrandic feature - the zone from the surface to 14 inches (A, Bw1 and Bw2 horizons)
Particle-size control section - the zone from 10 to 40 inches (Part of the Bw2, the 2Bw3 and part of the 2BC horizons)
Ranges in values listed under the A and Bw horizons for Volcanic glass content, Acid-oxalate extractable Al+1/2Fe, phosphate retention, 15-bar water, and Bulk density are estimates only.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
